chunks.text: So instead, what you could do is you could take a bunch

chunks.text: of smaller projectors, right?

chunks.text: And feed different inputs to each one of them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And as you're feeding different inputs,

chunks.text: And then you're going to be able to have

chunks.text: this really cool image on a very large stage.

chunks.text: So that's the idea of decomposition, OK?

chunks.text: You take the same projector, feed it different inputs.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It does the exact same thing behind the scenes,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: but it'll produce a different output for each one

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of these different inputs.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So these different devices are going to work together

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to achieve the same common goal.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's the idea of decomposition.

chunks.text: So these were applied to the problem

chunks.text: of projecting large image or a projector in general.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But we can apply these exact same concepts to programming.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So decomposition is really just the problem

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of creating structure in your code.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In the projector example, we have separate devices

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: working together.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In programming, to achieve decomposition,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you're dividing your code into smaller modules.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: These are going to be self-contained.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you can think of them as sort of little mini programs.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You feed in some input to them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: They do a little task.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then they give you something back.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: They go off and do their thing, and then they give back

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: a result. These modules can be used to break up your code.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the important thing is that they're reusable.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you write a module once, a little piece of code

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that does something once.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You debug it once.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then you can reuse it many, many times

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in your code with different inputs.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Benefit of this is it keeps your code organized

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and it keeps your code coherent.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So functions are going to be used to achieve decomposition

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and to create structure in our code.

chunks.text: We're going to see functions today in this lecture.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So decomposition is creating structure in your code.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And abstraction is the idea of suppressing details.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in the projector example, remember abstraction

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: was you didn't need to know exactly how the projector worked

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in order to use it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it's going to be the same idea in programming.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So once you write a piece of code that does a little task,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you don't need to rewrite that piece of code many times.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You've written it once.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you write this thing called a function specification for it,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or a doc string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this is a piece of text that tells anyone else who'd

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: want to use it in the future, other people, maybe yourself,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: it tells them how do you use this function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What inputs does it take?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What's the type of the inputs?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What is the function supposed to do?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And what is the output that you're going to get out of it?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So they don't need to know exactly how you implemented

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: They just need to know inputs, what it does,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: what's the output.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Those three things.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.
